results.justification: The study clearly states its aim: "This study explores whether and how GPT-4 can be leveraged to improve the readability of Swedish academic texts to support students’ reading practices."
Sections 3.1-3.4 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including data sourcing, prompting refinement, procedure, and analysis.
The document states: "All materials, scripts, and data can be accessed via OSF1."
Data is shared, so justification for not sharing is not applicable.
Table 1 provides characteristics of the original text, and Table 2 describes the prompt design. Further details are provided throughout section 3.
Section 3.1 details the data collection methods, specifying the source of the reading comprehension texts (SWESAT) and their accessibility.
The document states: "All materials, scripts, and data can be accessed via OSF1.", implying code is available.
Code is shared, so justification for not sharing is not applicable.
The document states: "All materials, scripts, and data can be accessed via OSF1.", implying code for data preparation is available.
Statistical tests (ANOVA, t-tests, Friedman test, Wilcoxon signed-rank tests) are clearly described in section 3.4.
Effect sizes, p-values, and descriptive statistics (Min, Mdn, Max, Mean, SD) are reported throughout section 4.
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
The study is primarily quantitative; data coding and analysis are not described in a qualitative manner.
Results are clearly presented in section 4, with tables summarizing key findings (Tables 3, 4, 5, 6).
Section 5.3 discusses limitations, including the potential limitations of the LIX score and the need for continued testing of LLMs.
The document does not mention or link to a preregistration.
